thread.title: Roger Federer and Serena Williams look to become oldest Wimbledon winners in the Open era
thread.title_full: Roger Federer and Serena Williams look to become oldest Wimbledon winners in the Open era - MarketWatch

author: By     Steven Kutz
title: Roger Federer and Serena Williams look to become oldest Wimbledon winners in the Open era
text:
In the Wimbledon finals this weekend, two of the older players on tour have a shot at winning titles.
Serena Williams, who is 33 years old, will play 21-year-old Garbine Muguruza on Saturday in the women’s final. And on Sunday, Roger Federer, who is also 33, will play 28-year-old Novak Djokovic.
In the Open era, 33 has historically been pretty old to be near the top of the rankings. For some perspective, Andy Roddick, who retired three years ago, is still just 32. The legend Bjorn Borg retired when he was 26. And Rafael Nadal has looked for most of 2015 like he can’t quite compete at the level he played at while winning 14 Grand Slam titles. He is 29.
If the oldsters end up winning, Federer would become the oldest man to win Wimbledon in the Open era, which began in 1968. Serena would become not only the oldest woman to win Wimbledon, but to win any Grand Slam tournament in the Open era.
They would also be setting some other impressive records. It would be Federer’s record eighth Wimbledon title. And it would earn Williams her second “Serena Slam” — which means she would hold all four Grand Slam titles at once.
Winners will receive $2.94 million, and runners-up will get $1.47 million.
The women’s final will be Saturday at 9 a.m. Eastern, and the men’s final will be on Sunday at 9 a.m. Eastern. Both will be on ESPN.
